turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Okay, I need some fashion advice! I'm trying to revamp my wardrobe but I'm on a tight budget. Like, REALLY tight. Say, $200 max for a whole outfit. Is that even possible?

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: Absolutely! Creating a stylish outfit for under $200 is definitely achievable. To give you the best recommendations, could you tell me a bit about your style preferences (e.g., casual, professional, trendy) and what kind of occasion you're dressing for? Also, what sizes do you typically wear?

turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Ugh, sizes are always a struggle! I'm usually a size 8, but it depends on the brand, doesn't it? As for style, I'm going for a smart casual look, something I can wear to the office but also out for drinks. And can you avoid recommending fast fashion brands? I'm trying to be more ethical with my clothing choices, even on a budget. Is that even possible?!

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: I understand your concerns! Ethical and affordable fashion can be tricky, but it's possible. One option is to check out consignment shops or online resale platforms like ThredUp or Poshmark for gently used, high-quality pieces. You can often find brands with ethical practices at significantly reduced prices. Another strategy is to focus on building a capsule wardrobe with versatile basics from brands that prioritize fair labor and sustainable materials, even if you only buy one or two items initially. For example, a well-fitting pair of sustainably sourced jeans ($50-$80 from a brand like Everlane or Pact), a neutral-colored blouse ($30-$50 from a brand like TenTree), and a blazer from a thrift store would easily fall within your budget and create a smart casual look. What do you think about these options?
